Message.Title: The Truth About Apple
Message.Msg: Foxconn put a freeze on recruitment until the end of March after more employees returned from the Chinese New Year break than a year earlier, company spokesman Bruce Liu said. It was not related to iPhone 5 production, he said. Foxconn is China’s largest private sector employer and the biggest assembler of Apple products. Later, UBS said in a research note that the freeze may be related to Hewlett-Packard (NYSE:HP) products… (Read more)

Message.Title: The TRUCH ABOUT The BBRY
Message.Msg: Some industry watchers had high hopes for BlackBerry’s (BBRY) first next-generation smartphone in its debut quarter, but it looks like they may have gotten ahead of themselves. Now, the Street is revising its estimates in light of a slower than expected rollout and what appears to be a softer launch than many had hoped for. Canaccord Genuity analyst T. Michael Walkley had initially called for BlackBerry to sell about 1.75 million BlackBerry Z10 smartphones in the February quarter. But after his checks following the phone’s launch in the UK and Canada found limited initial supply and softer than expected demand, the analyst slashed his estimates for the current quarter from 1.75 million units to just 300,000.

Message.Title: Reality FoxConn Hiring Freeze
Message.Msg: Does it really surprise anyone, that FoxConn has a production hiring freeze until end of March, given its already well-known first quarter after Christmas has seasonally lower production, every year? Is this not true for most every supplier that they sell the most the Christmas quarter, ramp up production before it, and slow down production after it. Apple did not forecast higher unit-sales this present quarter after Christmas. This should not surprise anyone. Also fact that higher % of FoxConn workers came back after Chinese New Years Week, than prior years should not surprise anyone... as their hourly pay was doubled to $2 an hour in the last 2 years.

Message.Title: Apple has big sales increase potential in India
Message.Msg: Tapping into the Indian Market.....from Credit Suisse ■ Apple setting its sights on India. Since the launch of iPhone 5, Apple has introduced a number of measures in India in order to improve its market positioning such as focus on advertising, partnering with national level distributors (Redington/Ingram Micro), offering interest free iPhone installments, building up its sales force, and recent launch of iTunes Store. This has allowed Apple to see improved traction in the Indian SP market with iPhone volumes recently seeing a 3-4x increase vs. previous quarter. This should allow Apple to grow its smartphone share in India going forward, which has been around 1-2% over the last few quarters. This year, the catalysts for Apple are more back half loaded with broader distribution through carriers and retail footprint expansion. ■ Apple remains on track to tap vast EM potential. Apple remains on track to tap the vast emerging market (EM) opportunity (see Emerging Apple:On track to realize potential, June 15, 2012). Given Apple’s relative under penetration in EMs, our proprietary top-down analysis reveals that the EM opportunity, together with momentum in developed markets could drive $159bn of incremental sales and $40 in incremental EPS by 2015. Retail expansion will be key here, note Apple has 400+ stores of which only 8 are in EMs (all in China). ■ EMs can add over $20 of EPS long term. In 2012, we estimate that the average middle class American (defined as $30,000+ of annual income) spent $417 per year on Apple products, which will rise to $500 by 2015. Importantly, by 2015, there will be 244mn consumers in EMs with similar income profiles (PPP adjusted), up from 133mn in 2011. From a distribution perspective, this could drive an incremental $89bn in sales and $21 of EPS by 2015. We estimate that BRIC + Mexico will account for ~70% of this incremental revenue opportunity. While we believe the current focus from the company is expansion on China and Brazil, we believe the moves in India are reassuring. ■ Valuation. Apple currently trades on 8x our calendar 2014 P/E, which is inexpensive given over 16% earnings growth between CY12–CY14 and net cash per share of $145. Our TP of $600, is based on a multiple of 10x applied to our taxed CY14 operating EPS of $59.

Message.Title: Possible information about Increased buybacks or increased dividend next week
Message.Msg: Apple may increase share buyback at shareholder meeting next week Apple's annual shareholders meeting is scheduled for next week and it's already generating a lot of press Karen Haslam Apple's annual shareholders meeting is scheduled for next week and it's already generating a lot of press thanks to Greenlight's David Einhorn who is suing Apple in order to block a proposal that is due to be voted on in at the shareholder meeting. Einhorn says that if shareholders vote for Proposal 2 Apple will be never be able to issue preferred stock, a scheme he is pitching for Apple to adopt. EInhorn believes Apple should return more of their $137 billion in the bank to investors in the form of preferred stock that will pay a 4% dividend to those who own it. Given the interest in whether Apple might direct some the huge stockpile of cash back to investors, it is expected that Apple will use the shareholder meeting to provide an update on its plans for capital allocation. The company may announce an increase to its current buyback plan, and it is likely that shareholders will hear an update on how much the company has spent so far on share buybacks. Apple announced in March 2012 that it would buy back $10 billion in stock over three years. Currently Apple is paying a $10.60 per year dividend with a yield of 2.3%. This compares favourably with the S&P 500 where the average is 2.1%. Intel pays the most at 4.3%, notes Forbes. The company had already spent $1.95 billion by December 2012, so "if it were to maintain that run-rate it would use up the $10 billion in just over five quarters," notes Forbes. The Forbes report looks into the likelihood of Apple increasing the dividend payment or increasing its Stock Buyback. One-time Apple dividend Forbes suggests that it is unlikely that Apple will pay a large one-time dividend. "If the company had wanted to do that it would have done it in 2012 when tax rates were lower," writes Chuck Jones. Instead he expects Apple to increase the dividend at a "measured pace". Share buyback As for a share buyback: "Apple would have to buyback 95 million shares at a cost of about $50 billion assuming an average cost of $525 per share due to the market reaction," suggests the report, which, it says would be "a stretch", and that's assuming it would not have to "bring back overseas cash and pay up to 35% in taxes on it." Einhorn's Preferred Stock scenario Forbes thinks it is unlikely that Apple will embark on "financial engineering" such as what David Einhorn is proposing with a 4% preferred stock. How much Apple has in the bank Forbes makes an interesting point about the money Apple has in the bank. "It has not been that long that Apple has had such a huge stockpile of cash and investments", writes Jones, noting that the company’s cash position ten years ago was about $4.3 billion, and five years ago the company had $15.4 billion. Follow Karen Haslam on Twitter / Follow MacworldUK on Twitter Related: Apple violating SEC laws and causing 'actual and imminent injury' to investors, claims Greenlight Apple responds to Greenlight's 'Attempt to interfere' Mass AAPL sell off by four hedge funds caused Apple stock price to plummet As Apple pays investors $2.5 billion dividend another investor sues Apple v Greenlight: $137b-case gets green light for early hearing What should Apple do with its $137b cash? AAPL action as investor threatens to sue and Apple issues statement Email Print Permalink Contact Us RSS ShareThis Digg You might like: Latest Mac Creative reviews (Macworld UK) The 50 best iOS games ever (Macworld UK) How to speed up a Mac hard disk (Macworld UK) The best iPad and iPhone apps (Macworld UK) Recommended by Comments What are your views on this subject? Use the form below to post a comment on this article up to 1000 characters. Comments received maccles said on Tue, 19 Feb 2013 It receives very little coverage in the press, but Apple can't just take its huge cash balance and pay it out to shareholders. The vast majority of this cash stock pile is held outside the USA. To pay it as dividends to shareholders, Apple must first bring the cash into the country - which means paying federal tax on it - maybe somewhere upwards of USD $10 billion to the US government. That is why Apple has been lobbying so hard for a tax amnesty for cash belonging to US companies that is held overseas - so it can take the opportunity to shift its money back to America. So far the share buy-back scheme and the dividends have all been paid for by Apple out of its domestic cash reserves. This has had the effect of skewing even further the proportion of their cash pile held overseas. Disclaimer Opinions expressed here are those of the writers and do not reflect those of Macworld. Message.Title: here is the news
Message.Msg: FoxConn Freezes Hiring On iPhone Production Slowdown First it was Walmart letting the truth finally slip last Friday when a leaked memo showed recent sales are a “total disaster.” Today, as anyone who has looked at AAPL premarket quotes will surmise, it’s Apple’s turn, following a report in the FT that FoxConn, the world’s largest contract electronics manufacturer, “has imposed a recruitment freeze across almost all of its factories in China 5th as it slows production of Apple’s iPhone.” It is not an internal memo, but in this particular case actions speak even louder than leaked words: ‘The suspension in hiring by China’s largest private sector employer, and the biggest assembler of Apple products, is the first search countrywide move since the 2009 downturn, prompted by the financial crisis. It underscores the weakening demand for some Apple products, Which has put pressure on the American company’s battered share price. “Currently, none of the plants in mainland China have hiring plans,” said Liu Kun, a company spokesman at Foxconn’s largest manufacturing facility in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen.”

Drown the noise out and use you own mind. Think for yourselves. Message.Title: IWATCH
Message.Msg: Apple has filed a patent for an iWatch-like device with a flexible touchscreen display, Mikey Campbell of AppleInsider reports . The patent, which Apple filed with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office in August 2011, is for a "Bi-stable spring with flexible display" that conforms to your wrist or other parts of the body. The device, according to the patent, would have a continuous display and be able to connect with other portable devices, like the iPhone and even more basic handsets, via Bluetooth or Wi-Fi. With the device, users would be able to do things like adjust the order of a playlist, see recent phone calls, and respond to text messages, according to the patent. Speculation regarding the iWatch has heated up recently, and Apple reportedly has 100 people working on a smartwatch.

Message.Title: Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL): iPhone 5 and iPhone 4S are two most popular smartphones in the world
Message.Msg: "In the fourth quarter of the previous year, iPhone 5 of Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) was the world’s bestselling smartphone which was followed by the iPhone 4S indicating that it was the second most popular, even more than Samsung’s Galaxy S3. According to the new data that was received from the Strategy Analytics, during the holiday quarter, Apple has shipped 27.4 million iPhones . That amounted to about 13% share of the smartphones that are shipped globally. On the other hand, 17.4 million units of the iPhone 4S were shipped during the fourth quarter. So, even after being launched in the year 2011, the iPhone 4S managed to grab 8% of the smartphone market even after the iPhone 5 was released. According to Strategy Analytics’ Senior Analyst, Neil Shah, the iPhone 5 and the iPhone 4S are presently the two most popular models of smartphones in the world. Together they have been able to take over 21% of the global smartphone market, that is not even inclusive of iPhone 4. According to Neil Mawston, the Executive Director at Strategy Analytics, the performance of iPhone has been pretty impressive considering the premium pricing of the devices. The third most popular smartphone is the Samsung Galaxy S3, that shipped 15.4 million pieces in the fourth quarter. It has 7% share of the global smartphone market. This model of Samsung has enjoyed a lot of popularity over a long time in North America, Asia and Europe. However, the demand for the Samsung Galaxy S3 has increased and under such circumstances the company will be very eager to launch its Galaxy S4 in the forthcoming weeks so that it can compete with the Apple’s iPhone range. Though Galaxy S3 was outsold by the iPhone 5, it did not come as a surprise as Samsung had launched its handset a long time before Apple."

Message.Msg: Unbelievable how management - Tim Cook - could have taken us from $705 to now close to $440 and mybe lower. I am a long term conservative investor and genrally takes a lot to pi** me off. But management has really dropped the ball here in allowing us to play second fiddle to Google. From making it a crusade to take every patent infringement case to the mat and losing most, to failing to prpoerly utilize the incredible resources at our disposal to crush our competitors. Where the heck is the new product development. Why are we being out run by Samsung. Is Cook playing to win or tio lose. Do something creative and make sure it is better than just an increased buyback or dividends though that would help. Supply bottlenecks, faulty maps,,,there seems to be a never ending parade of failure. I would hope that Cook et al would forgo any bonuses this year. They don't deserve them. And what is happening with increasing footprint in China. Not enough. Your report card reads "Has the ability but could do so much better". Steve would be very disappointed. He deosn't like to lose and doesn't suffer fools. Get busy!.

Topic.Title: Apple Board Needs to Fire Tim Cook!

Message.Msg: Long-time apple bull, but I am starting to think along these lines myself. TC is responsible for managing both Apple the hardware/software maker and aapl the WS paper company. He may be executing well on item 1, but he is floundering on item 2 and has lost the confidence of the investment community; not a matter of right or wrong, but he has lost the confidence, and that is difficult to re-establish. Assuming he is not acting at the direction of the BOD on item 2, then it may be time for the BOD to switch horses - nolo contendere - put someone in charge who can handle 2 better and let TC run 1.

Topic.Title: Apple Board Needs to Fire Tim Cook!

Message.Msg: For over a decade, Apple was/is a great company with great products. But it was also a cult. And sadly, the cult leader (Steve Jobs) has passed on. The products are still great. The company still has an excellent balance sheet, but the boat sails on without a rudder. Tim Cook is a competent CEO and up to the task of running Apple, but he is no Steve Jobs. Millions of people worldwide would have jumped off a cliff if Jobs had told them too, but not anymore. So, what exactly do we have here in the new Apple. A company with great products, fine management and a continuing bright future. It will trade in a range and continue to reward, but don't expect a straight line up into infinity for the stock price. If that were ever to have been the case (doubtful), it died with Steve Jobs.

Topic.Title: beyond ridiculous

Message.Msg: Even I feel like I can't take much more of this. I've been through this a few times: when one has seen a floor and then fallen through it...as if to the basement floor...loaded up and somehow fallen again, to what seems like the bedrock, and then still fall! When even the most ardent bulls question their sense of reality--when somehow the price action has us feeling like down is (not just more likely) but inevitable--when your neo cortex wants to invest the the limbic brain has taken over and is running the show, then we'll be at a bottom. Sadly the vast majority of folks won't be able to buy at, or even near the bottom, because their emotions won't allow it. I confess I may be there now. ~Mark

Message.Title: Apple: CNBC Again Hosts McLean Opining $200/Sh Possible Vanity fair right on the money.
Message.Msg: Vanity Fair magazine contributor Bethany Mclean was invited on CNBC once again this morning to chat with Squawk on the Street’s Carl Quintanilla about here views on Apple (AAPL). Mclean, who is credited with calling the demise of Enron, has been on CNBC previously this month opining that Apple shares could go to $200. Mclean opines Apple is losing the smartphone wars, and it’s not clear the company can turn it around: It’s as much likely to see $200 as $1,000. I think there are a lot of questions. Basically, the opacity of its earnings power. Basically it’s a phone company with a few other businesses. Basically now it’s losing the operating system battle to Android. What are hedge fund managers and young kids carrying? They’re carrying an S 3. Basically, Apple is holding onto women in the developed world. The more Google wins in Mobile, the more APple loses. On Android, Google search is 30% to 40% more profitable. Now Apple could still come out with a product out of nowhere. They have a history of doing that, albeit under other management. So, it’s not a straight line to Apple $200, Google $1,000.

Message.Title: Apple iWatch, Wearable Devices Seen Taking Off
Message.Msg: ABI says that with a wave of new gadgets set to hit the consumer market, wearable devices could soon become the norm within five years. ABI also forecasts that the wearable computing device market will grow to 485 million annual device shipments by 2018. Reports Thursday say Apple made a patent filing with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office in August 2011 that hints it's developing a flexible touch-screen device that fits around a user's wrist. Some analysts say an "iWatch" rollout will come this year, as IBD has reported. Google (GOOG), meanwhile, is launching an augmented-reality smart-glass product called Google Glass. "Apple's curved glass-based watch could prove to be a revelation in the wearable technologies market. The major question is whether the digital timepiece will act as a complimentary device to the company's iPhone smartphones or as a standalone product with other functionalities like health or activity tracking capabilities," Josh Flood, an analyst at ABI Research, said in the firm's report.

Message.Title: How AAPL can get Back to 20 PE
Message.Msg: As soon as Apple has moderate priced phone for Third World Market, and even lower-priced / lower performance model, GOOG / Android will no longer be seen as having that market "abdicated" to them. And soon AAPL will have a 20+ PE just like it used to have and like GOOG now has. Apple can't be content only having its Smartphones way outsell Samsung's highest priced Galaxy Phones. Time for Apple to also outdo Samsung in the lower and mid-cost phones important for the third world as well.

Message.Title: Dear Einhorn - AAPL doesn't need to borrow cash
Message.Msg: Please don't con Apple into borrowing money preferred stocks. Apple doesn't need to borrow cash that would only defer the repatriation tax Apple would have to pay later. The repatriation tax rate will probably be higher in the future. The rate Apple earns on the offshore money would never make up for the rate Apple would pay for the loans, bonds or preferred stocks. If Apple must return more money to shareholders, have a steady increase in the common shareholder dividend over the next few years, and maybe repatriate a little of the offshore cash, especially during times more offshore cash accumulates.

Message.Title: Billionaire Chase Coleman and Feroz Dewan’s Top Picks for 2013
Message.Msg: Although Tiger’s top pick is still Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL), Coleman reduced his position in the stock by almost 20%, cutting his portfolio percentage holding from 12% to slightly over 10%. We side with the majority of analysts who feel that AAPL is undervalued at current levels, especially taking into consideration the decline in price since the start of the year. The stock is seemingly light-years away from its 52-week high price of $705, but if it just reached Wall Street's consensus target a year from today, investors could capture almost 40% of upside from current levels. We still like AAPL from a valuation and dividend standpoint, and Coleman still has plenty of skin in the game, as does fellow billionaire David Einhorn

Message.Title: 4 Stocks That May Hit $1,000 Before Google
Message.Msg: . As big as Google may be, it's still growing at an astounding clip. Revenue soared 36% in its latest quarter! Sure, a good chunk of that came from the Motorola Mobility acquisition, but even if you back that out, the online titan still grew its revenue 22% during the holiday quarter. However, there are also plenty of other companies trading in the triple digits that may have their eyes set on the $1,000 finish line. Let's look at a few that may -- if things go right -- beat Google to 1k. Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL ) -- $448.85 If analysts scrambling to slap four-figure price targets on Google sounds familiar, it's because a couple of Wall Street pros were doing the same thing to Apple when it was topping $700 late last year. The good times didn't last. Apple has come through with a few disappointing quarters, and the fear these days is that Google's Android is eating Apple's lunch. Apple's future will be challenging, especially as it tries to make its high-priced products more accessible to mainstream audiences worldwide. The market has marked down the shares as a result of declining margins and slowing growth, but the market can't forget that Apple is an innovator. The iPad and iPhone -- two product lines that account for the lion's share of Apple's revenue and profitability these days -- didn't even exist six years ago. When Apple disrupts again, and it will, the market will reward the stakeholders

Message.Title: No value created by Einhorn plan whatsoever
Message.Msg: If I have a dollar and give you ten dimes or four quarters have I created any additional value? Not really. This is all iPref's do. He's trying to market ten dimes as being more valuable than a dollar. You cannot make something from nothing. The market has and will assign apple a value. Dividends and iPref's won't change it. The only thing that could change it is a massive buyback which would be accretive to earnings. EPS would go up as share count went down. Since cash now makes no money all apple has to do is earn more than 3% a year and buying back shares here are accretive to EPS. Will they do it? Hell no! Apple management and board only cares about themselves. Shareholders are of no concern whatsoever. Never have been and never will. Not unless you fire Cook and the entire board. Rather than do that just sell it and move on to greater tickers. Many co's out there with more growth ahead for years. Take a look at KORS for one example. Estimates were 41 cents. They did 64 cents. 50% plus beat. Massive YOY growth. Why play with apple at zero to negative growth when so many co's out there have years of runway ahead. Kors can be a 5 or 10 bagger. Apple can NEVER do that from here.

Message.Title: APPLE
Message.Msg: Apple might not be the granddaddy of them all, but the cool factor surrounding the iPad and iPhone are hard to ignore. And the company's fans are … well ...fanatical. Still, the company seems to justify it. Right now the firm's stock is down, as you should already know. But I continue to believe this is a strong buy opportunity. With 20% of U.S. tech sales coming from the firm there's going to be support for Apple. So if you have it, keep it. Don't let the herd stampede you. If you don't have it, now's the time to buy it. I think Apple bounces back by $100 within a year.

Message.Title: I actually took the time to listen to Eignhorn and...
Message.Msg: He makes a great case. He calls the shares IPREFS and they would unlock much more shareholder value while allowing Apple to keep its' already huge pile of cash. He took the time to compare all ways to return cash to shareholders and,i am convinced, his way is the best way for both the shareholder and the company . To be sure it is going to be exceedingly more difficult for Cook and company to justify allowing this cash to pile up. Eignhorn made a comparison with Dell. He said he sold Dell last year because they kept making the case that they couldn't bring overseas cash home because of the tax situation. NOW they are using the cash to leverage a buyout that is benefiting Michael Dell more than shareholders. In other words when it was shareholder money it couldn't be used becuase it was overseas. But when it was his money it could be leveraged to the hilt. Eignhorn is not suggesting that Apple leverage anything but his point was clear. Apple could do whatever they want but the IPREFS will unlock more value and allow Apple to maintain its cash pile. I call that a win win even though I have serious doubts that Apple will do it this time around.

Message.Title: CNBC - very sad.... Internal infection of cynicism and disrespect.
Message.Msg: It is very sad to see how sloppy, and unprofessional many of the talking heads have become over the past ten years. It is also sad to see how the cynical and abrasive nature of a few have infected others on the set. I long for objective reporting of events, without the spin of individuals who have , no,track records of success or knowledge of many of the subjects on which they pontificate. It would be nice to see a bit more kindness , professionalism, thoughtful responses, and a little due diligence before reporting rumors as facts. I would also like to see some accountability, be it a website, or posting(s) , where an individual can see the accuracy of the predictions of their panels and guests. Bottom line... A bit of respect, objectivity less drama and accountability for thier actions could go a long way to increase quality viewership.

Message.Title: What is preferred shares and why does Einhorn want you to vote no to proposition 2?
Message.Msg: Preferred shares are usually used by a company to raise cash in the situation that it has difficulty raising fund in the bond market. Selling or issuing of preferred shares are often negotiated between the company and the buyer(s) in private. Remember GS sold $5B preferred at 10% yield to Buffett in 2008? It was a great deal for Buffett but the common shareholders of GS kept going down (BTW, GS bought those preferred back from Buffett in 2011). That is the reason Einhorn wants you to vote no to proposition 2. He wants Apple management to privately issue preferred to him and other big funds. If proposition 2 approved, Apple management will not be able to do that unless majority of common share holders approve. Apple doesn’t need to raise cash. Preferred shares will dilute the value of common shares. Only the preferred shares holders, the ones negotiated with Apple management will get the high dividends, common share holders will not. Don’t let Einhorn fool you.

Message.Title: IWatch Patent Application Today!!!
Message.Msg: Today, the US Patent & Trademark Office published a patent application from Apple that reveals an advanced wearable computer in the form of a bracelet that could double as a watch. That's the key, as the bracelet goes far beyond being a wristwatch. Apple states that with a multitouch display, the user "can accomplish a number of different tasks including adjusting the order of a current playlist, or reviewing a list of recent phone calls. A response to a current text message can even be managed given a simple virtual keyboard configuration across the face of the flexible display." Apple also contemplates utilizing a solar panel beneath the display as well as take advantage of kinetic energy. This is one hot little invention and the drum that's been beating very loudly of late calling for an iWatch, appears to be well into development.

Message.Title: The iWatch (info)
Message.Msg: Is This the Apple Watch We’re Waiting For? By Aabha Rathee | More Articles February 21, 2013 Page 1 of 2 A device in a patent application filed by Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) sounds incredibly like the touch screen smart watch the company has been rumored to have in its pipeline. The watch is designed to use Corning’s (NYSE:GLW) flexible Willow glass. The application, filed with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office in August 2011 and discovered by AppleInsider on Thursday, is for a wearable accessory that has a flexible touch screen display and uses a “slap bracelet” mechanism to conform to the user’s arm. The device, described as a Bi-stable spring with flexible display, connects to a phone or another mobile device through Bluetooth and Wi-Fi. The accessory can turn into an uninterrupted screen when in its “curled state,” with gyroscopes and accelerometers orienting the screen toward the user. “With a touch screen user input a user can accomplish a number of different tasks including adjusting the order of a current playlist, and reviewing a list of recent phone calls,” the application reads. “A response to a current text message can even be managed given a simple virtual keyboard configuration across the face of the flexible display.” Several materials can be used to create the bracelet holding the device together, including steel or even Velcro…

Message.Title: Einhorn
Message.Msg: Einhorn spent most of the call outlining his plan for "perpetual preferred stock," or what he calls 'iPrefs." These are preferred shares that have a base value of $50 and would pay a dividend worth $2 per year for each share. He said this would satisfy demand in the market for "safe income paying instruments" with little risk to Apple's existing cash flow. Such "iPrefs" would also trade on the market. Einhorn recommends that Apple "start small" with about $50 billion worth, to give the market for these new types of securities a chance to stabilize. "As a result of the zero-rate interest policy, there is a widespread need for safe income," Einhorn said, noting that such shares would help Apple appeal to a new class of income-oriented investors without forcing changes to its existing shareholder base. In comparison to other cash return moves, such as increasing the size of Apple's existing dividend, or buying back more shares, Einhorn said his plan offers shareholders "much greater bang for the buck in terms of value unlocked per dollar distributed." He added that his plan for the iPrefs would not benefit most other companies that are currently valued in line with their "intrinsic values" by investors. "But Apple is different. Apple is not appropriately capitalized. It is not minimizing its cost of capital," he said. "This is one reason why we believe Apple's shares trade at a valuation well below its intrinsic value."

Topic.Title: Samsung Galaxy S4

Message.Msg: Let me give you my personnel experience about Galaxy S3....I had first bought Iphone 5 late last year and it was an excellent phone in terms of quick connectivity, quality of voice and super fast internet. BUT since it was a small screen, I changed to S3 within those 14 days they give you. I can tell you ( and this is exactly the experience of my freind Ron) that this was the worst decision I made. The internet connectivity speed sucks.. Too many dropped calls , garbled in coming sound and the speakerphone sounds like a you get the sound in an automobile when the speaker diaphragm is broken. I will have to live with this piece of junk for another 20 months . I regret my decision because Iphone was a beautifully engineered piece of equipment with excellent working features. Today I had a fully charged battery at 8AM and with little use and an hour's use of GPS, my battery was dead by 2PM. I think this is going to ultimately effect Samsung and its temporary hype and Apple will emerge stronger as a quality product. Yes the stock can come down to 425 range along with market correction, BUT I am confident that Apple's best days are still ahead as people get fed up with other brands.

Topic.Title: This Aapl story with Einhorn is not Good...Who appointed this Doosh ?

Message.Msg: Einhorn is trying to unlock the value of AAPL (not Apple) and this is a very good way to do it. Einhorn is wealthy because he's brilliant - not the other way around. His approach is innovative and tax-friendly to the company and the investor. But the investors (real investors) will decide that he is right or wrong with their vote. If the vote defeats #2 then Apple BOD still have to decide whether to follow the voters' desires or not. This is certainly not binding, merely barometric. But I think it's a clever idea.

Message.Title: I'm seeing max pain about 460 for tomorrow.
Message.Msg: I think we may see some upside tomorrow afternoon. It could close green and it could go up significantly if management responds in any way to Einhorn, Remember last week Einhorn filed suit and the stock went one day, languished the next until Cook said that they would consider his ideas. The stock shot up after that. Cook won't say anything or he'll say something neutral. So if there is any response at all, it;s likely to drive the stock up. If there is no response (which is likely IMO), then we will be at the mercy of Friday MM action and who knows. Max pain and real pain last week ranged 490-430 and we ended at 460. Should be an interesting day. GLTA.

Topic.Title: PE of 5 ?

Message.Msg: And why do you think Tim Cook apologized for Apple Maps? Why did they fire Scott Forstall when he wouldn't apologize? Because Apple asked its customers to switch from Google to Apple Maps, and dropped the ball. That is unacceptable and for a lesser company would be unforgivable. At some point in the future, Apple will again ask its customers to switch, but this time it will be for search. They will only have one chance to get it right. On a side note, the Maps program is also a move towards search. Local search that is. Local search will prove more profitable to the winner than the present general information search. Maps is an important tool in the battle for local search and local search is an area where google does not have as dominant an advantage. In fact, a few players are actually better positioned than Google.

Topic.Title: Another week, another 2m+ iphones sold..

Message.Msg: Foxconn just went through a year where they were forced to greatly improve pay and working conditions. The reality is is that Foxconn's employment is at record levels, and with the better pay and conditions, worker turnover after Chinese New Year was greatly reduced. I know people want to make hay of this, or even blame it on HP, but reality is is that it is about lower worker turnover. BTW, this is actually a positive because quality control and productivity should be greatly improved.
